_prev_prog_3.PC_OtherType: Barriers, separation from process units, melt plugs
_prev_prog_3.Description: Chlorination of refinery process cooling water.  This process includes five separate areas: four cooling towers where there are two interconnected cylinders and one storage area where there are up to six (nonconnected) cylinders.

Loading, storage & unloading of Liquefied Petroleum Gas (LPG).  This process exists in four separate areas: 1) a tank farm consisting of twelve "bullet" tanks containing propane, n-butane, isobutane, and "olefins"; and 2) a single sphere tank containing isobutane; 3) truck loading/unloading facilities; and 4) rail loading/unloading facilities.
HF Alkylation Unit.  This process produces high-octane gasoline blendstock by reacting light hydrocarbons in the presence of hydrofluoric acid.
Butamer Unit.  This process converts normal butane into isobutane for use as a feed to the HF Alkylation Unit.
Crude Unit.  This process uses distillation to separate crude oil into its component fractions.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Executive Summary
Frontier Refining Inc.
Risk Management Program

Frontier?s Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies
It is Frontier?s policy to design, construct, operate, and maintain the equipment at the Cheyenne Refinery so that no accidental releases of any chemical occur that would negatively impact people or the environment.  To this end, Frontier?s staff strives to conduct all activities in accordance with industry standards.  Frontier considers safety as a condition of employment and emphasizes safety in the workplace.  Personnel are required to demonstrate their commitment to safety by regularly attending safety meetings, being involved in one of two behavior-based safety programs, and undergoing regular refresher training on safety and environmental topics.

Source Description and Part 68 Regulated Substances Handled 
Frontier Refining Incorporated?s (Frontier?s) Cheyenne Refinery processes approximately 46,000 barrels per day of crude oil supplied from Canada, Wyoming, and adjacent states.  The refinery consists of approximately fifteen process units that separate, chemically react, and finally blend the crude oil components into gasoline, diesel, asphalt, petroleum coke, and other products.  In addition, the refinery has over one hundred storage tanks for storing the raw materials, intermediates, and products prior to shipment by pipeline or truck.

Three 40 CFR Part 68 regulated substances are present in the processes at the Frontier facility in amounts above the specified threshold quantities.  These substances are common to most petroleum refineries and are:

?    Chlorine, used to control algae growth in the refinery?s cooling towers.  Chlorine is a gas at normal conditions and is toxic above a certain concentration in the air.
?    NFPA 4 flammable mixtures that contain the regulated substances hydrogen, methane, ethane, propane, propene, butane, isobutane, butene, and/or pentane.  These substances are chemically reacted and/or blend

ed into gasoline and are flammable or explosive under certain conditions.
?    Anhydrous hydrogen fluoride (HF), used as a catalyst in Frontier?s Alkylation Unit.  HF is a gas at normal conditions and is toxic above a certain concentration in the air.

Frontier?s Accidental Release Program & Chemical Specific Prevention Steps
Frontier implements and administers the RMP accidental release program through OSHA?s Process Safety Management (PSM) program, which requires the same program elements.  Frontier has an individual designated as the PSM Coordinator who is responsible for the implementation and administration of the program.  There are eleven processes at the refinery which contain RMP-regulated substances above threshold quantities:

?    Cooling Water Treatment (chlorine)
?    LPG Storage (NFPA 4 flammables)
?    HF Alkylation Unit (NFPA 4 flammables and hydrofluoric acid)
?    Butamer Unit (NFPA 4 flammables)
?    Crude Unit (NFPA 4 flammables)
?    Naphtha Hydrotreating (Hydrobon) Unit (NFPA 4 flammables)
?    Catalytic Reforming (Platformer) Unit (NFPA 4 flammables)
?    Gasoline Hydrotreating (Scanfiner) Unit (NFPA 4 flammables)
?    Fluid Catalytic Cracking Unit (FCCU) (NFPA 4 flammables)
?    Gas Concentration Unit (NFPA 4 flammables)
?    Delayed Coking Unit (NFPA 4 flammables)

Chlorine is stored at the facility in 2,000 lb cylinders only.  This limits the amount that could be released by a cylinder failure.  

NFPA 4 flammable mixtures are used in several areas throughout the plant.  Frontier?s personnel are trained to be very aware of hydrocarbon leaks.  Through the Hot Work Permit program and the Leak Detection and Repair (LDAR) program, regular monitoring is conducted with calibrated instruments to check for and direct the repair of leaks.  Operators in all units have hand-held monitors for the detection of hydrocarbons, and several units have fixed hydrocarbon detectors.  Frontier also maintains firewater monitors, deluge systems, and water curtains near the areas.  

HF acid is pres

ent only in the Alkylation Unit.  All personnel entering the unit receive special HF acid training prior to being allowed to enter.  Frontier?s personnel are trained to be very aware of HF leaks.  In addition, equipment connections are painted with a reactive paint that changes color in the presence of HF.  This provides indication of any leak at a connection.  In addition to the HF-specific measures, the measures outlined previously for NFPA 4 flammable substances also apply at the Alkylation Unit.  These measures are effective at detecting and mitigating HF leaks, since in most places in the unit, hydrocarbons are present with the HF acid, and HF acid is very soluble in water.  Open-path hydrocarbon monitors are installed in the unit.  Finally, closed-circuit video cameras are placed throughout the unit to aid the operators? monitoring of the unit and direct the deluge water cannons in the event of a release.

Frontier?s Five Year Accident History
In the past five years, Frontier has had no accidental releases from covered processes that resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage on site, or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage.

Frontier?s Emergency Response Program
General
All refinery personnel, contract workers, and unescorted visitors are required to complete an annual basic facility hazards awareness program prior to proceeding onto the operational areas of the refinery.  This program includes how to recognize emergency alarms and what to do in the event an alarm is sounded.   

Frontier Employees
A majority of the refinery?s non-managerial and non-administrative employees, as well as some contractors undergo annual first responder training (approx. 4 hours).  This covers usage of a self-contained breathing apparatus, basic awareness of Frontier?s firefighting equipment, fire extinguisher training on a live fire, and usage of a fire hose.

Fire Brigade
Frontier?s Fire Bri

gade is comprised of thirty-seven facility personnel that respond to refinery emergency situations involving fires and/or hazardous materials, including those subject to RMP.  Fire Brigade personnel receive an initial 32-hour training in industrial firefighting at either Texas A&M University Fire School or University of Nevada-Elko Fire Science Academy and an initial 24-hour training in OSHA HAZWOPER held locally.  The Fire Brigade personnel also drill once a month for approximately four hours, attend an eight-hour HAZWOPER refresher course annually, and attend another 32-hour industrial firefighting course every three years.

Frontier maintains an on-site firehouse with several firefighting vehicles: a fast-attack truck, a 1000-gallon foam pumper, a 1250-gpm pumper engine, a 2000-gpm ?Hired Gun? self-educting foam nozzle trailer, and a 1250-gallon foam nurse trailer.  A 1250-gpm ?Telesquirt? pumper/ladder engine and a hazardous materials (HAZMAT) response trailer are stored offsite.  The HAZMAT trailer contains equipment primarily for spill containment and cleanup.  Frontier also maintains a live fire fighting facility onsite.

Medical Personnel
Nineteen of Frontier?s employees are trained to respond to medical injuries to the Basic Emergency Care level.  This training consists of an initial 40-hour training as well as ongoing continuing education requirements and biannual certification.  Frontier also has one nurse on duty at the facility and three employees who are certified Emergency Medical Technicians.  Frontier retains a company doctor who has an office off site.

Incident Command 
Frontier has three employees trained as Incident Commanders using the National Interagency Incident Management System (NIIMS) Incident Command System (ICS).  These employees have received an initial eight-hour training in ICS.  Frontier conducts tabletop ICS drills approximately once a month.  Each incident commander, as well as other employees serving in the ICS, attend approximat

ely three such drills per year.

In addition to the control rooms in the individual process units, Frontier?s facility is equipped with an underground central control room that can be used to control the facility remotely during an emergency.  An emergency operations center is located in close proximity to the central control room.

Offsite Responders Coordination
Frontier?s Fire Brigade participates in drills with the City of Cheyenne Fire Rescue once or twice a year and Frontier is a member of, and the Fire Chief participates in, the Laramie County Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC).  Emergency releases and significant fires are reported to the local 911, Laramie County LEPC, Wyoming Department of Homeland Security and Emergency Management, Wyoming Department of Environmental Quality, and/or the National Response Center, as regulations require.  

Frontier is a founding member of the Laramie County Industrial Mutual Aid Organization, which includes the City and County fire departments as well as several industrial and military fire departments in the area.  The mutual aid organization can provide additional response equipment, materials, and personnel in the event of a large emergency.  The organization maintains and updates a directory of mutual aid resources.
  
Community Notification
Frontier participates in an emergency notification and response program developed and implemented by the LEPC, the Wyoming Department of Environmental Quality and the Laramie County Emergency Manager.  Additionally, Frontier participates in the area?s Shelter In Place program for nearby residents and other population.   The Shelter In Place program is a countywide effort that provides information and procedures for potential citizens on what they should do regarding emergency situations in the vicinity of their residence or place of work.  This Shelter In Place program is communicated directly to the local residents and other potentially impacted populace by a variety of people an

d organizations, including senior refinery management.

Frontier?s Planned Changes to Improve Safety at the Facility
During 2003, Frontier invested considerable time, effort, and money in increasing the safety performance at the plant.  The refinery saw a large reduction in the OSHA incident rates and was awarded three safety performance awards by the National Petrochemical and Refiners? Association, three by the National Safety Council, and two by OSHA.  In June of 2004, Frontier employees completed one million man-hours without a lost-time injury.  Frontier is committed to continual improvement in safety.  

To this end, the following activities are planned for the future:

?    Integrate and update the refinery?s emergency preparedness and response plans into a single plan.

?    Add foam fire suppression systems to certain tanks (external floaters).

?    Build a new firehouse and purchase a new fire truck (long range plan).

?    Increase fireproofing in process areas.

?    Continue to support behavioral safety programs and safety performance improvement in general.
